questions.question: A skateboarder is traveling at an initial speed of $6.5\text{ m/s}$ when they reach a rough patch of pavement that is $12\text{ m}$ long. If they exit the patch at a speed of $3.2\text{ m/s}$, calculate the skateboarder's constant acceleration (assumed uniform) while on the rough patch.
A Tesla accelerates uniformly from rest to a speed of $28\text{ m/s}$ (approximately $100\text{ km/h}$) in $3.1\text{ s}$. Determine the distance covered during this sprint.
questions.explanation: Using $s = \frac{u+v}{2} \times t$: $s = \frac{0+28}{2} \times 3.1 = 14 \times 3.1 = 43.4 \approx 43\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A camera is accidentally dropped by a tourist from a hot air balloon that is hovering stationary at a height of $110\text{ m}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the camera's speed after it has fallen for $4.0\text{ s}$.
questions.explanation: Using $v = u + gt$ with $u = 0$: $v = 0 + 9.8(4.0) = 39.2 \approx 39\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A ball is thrown straight upward and reaches a maximum height of $14\text{ m}$ above its release point. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the total time it spends in the air before returning to the thrower's hand.
questions.explanation: First find initial velocity: $v^2 = u^2 - 2gh \rightarrow 0 = u^2 - 2(9.8)(14) \rightarrow u = \sqrt{274.4} = 16.56\text{ m/s}$. Time to peak: $t_{up} = u/g = 16.56/9.8 = 1.69\text{ s}$. Total time = $2 \times 1.69 \approx 3.38 \approx 3.4\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A rescue package is released from a plane traveling horizontally at $65\text{ m/s}$ at an altitude of $320\text{ m}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the horizontal distance from the drop point to the landing site.
questions.explanation: Time of fall: $320 = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 = 4.9t^2 \rightarrow t = \sqrt{320/4.9} = \sqrt{65.31} = 8.08\text{ s}$. Horizontal distance: $d = v_x t = 65 \times 8.08 \approx 525.2 \approx 525\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A golfer chips a ball with an initial speed of $15\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $55^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the time it takes for the ball to reach its maximum height.
questions.explanation: Vertical component: $u_y = 15\sin(55^{\circ}) = 15(0.8192) = 12.29\text{ m/s}$. Time to peak: $t = u_y/g = 12.29/9.8 \approx 1.254 \approx 1.25\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A snowball is thrown at $12\text{ m/s}$ from the roof of a building that is $10\text{ m}$ high, at an angle of $20^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Calculate its horizontal range (the distance from the base of the building where it lands). Neglect air resistance.

A boat can travel at $4.2\text{ m/s}$ in still water. The pilot aims the boat at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ upstream relative to the straight-across direction to counteract a river current. If the boat ends up moving straight across the river (perpendicular to the banks), calculate the boat's resulting speed relative to the shore.
questions.explanation: The upstream component of the boat's velocity is $4.2\sin(30^{\circ}) = 2.1\text{ m/s}$, which cancels the current. The component perpendicular to the banks is $4.2\cos(30^{\circ}) = 4.2(0.8660) \approx 3.64 \approx 3.6\text{ m/s}$. This is the boat's speed relative to the shore.

questions.question: Car X is moving East at a constant speed of $90\text{ km/h}$ and Car Y is moving East at a constant speed of $115\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the velocity of Car Y relative to Car X.
questions.explanation: Relative velocity: $\vec{v}_{Y/X} = \vec{v}_Y - \vec{v}_X = 115\text{ km/h East} - 90\text{ km/h East} = 25\text{ km/h East}$.

questions.question: A lawnmower of mass $24\text{ kg}$ is pushed with a force of $110\text{ N}$ directed at an angle of $35^{\circ}$ below the horizontal. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the mower and the ground is $\mu_k = 0.22$, calculate the acceleration of the mower.
questions.explanation: Horizontal component: $F_x = 110\cos35^{\circ} = 110(0.8192) = 90.1\text{ N}$. Vertical component (downward): $F_y = 110\sin35^{\circ} = 110(0.5736) = 63.1\text{ N}$. Normal force: $N = mg + F_y = 24(9.8) + 63.1 = 235.2 + 63.1 = 298.3\text{ N}$. Friction: $f_k = \mu_k N = 0.22(298.3) = 65.6\text{ N}$. Net force: $F_{net} = 90.1 - 65.6 = 24.5\text{ N}$. Acceleration: $a = F_{net}/m = 24.5/24 \approx 1.02 \approx 1.0\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A hockey puck of mass $0.50\text{ kg}$ is sliding on ice at an initial speed of $14\text{ m/s}$. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the puck and the ice is $0.08$, how much time will it take for the puck to come to a complete stop?
questions.explanation: Deceleration due to friction: $a = -\mu g = -0.08(9.8) = -0.784\text{ m/s}^2$. Using $v = u + at$: $0 = 14 - 0.784t \rightarrow t = 14/0.784 \approx 17.86 \approx 18\text{ s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the net force required to bring a car of mass $1500\text{ kg}$ traveling at $25\text{ m/s}$ to a complete stop over a distance of $60\text{ m}$, assuming constant deceleration.
questions.explanation: First find acceleration using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$: $0 = (25)^2 + 2a(60) \rightarrow 0 = 625 + 120a \rightarrow a = -625/120 = -5.208\text{ m/s}^2$. Then force: $F = m|a| = 1500(5.208) \approx 7812 \approx 7800\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A block of mass $8.5\text{ kg}$ is held stationary on a frictionless incline making an angle of $25^{\circ}$ with the horizontal by a string parallel to the ramp. Calculate the tension in the string.
questions.explanation: On a frictionless incline, the tension balances the component of weight down the ramp: $T = mg\sin\theta = 8.5(9.8)\sin(25^{\circ}) = 83.3(0.4226) \approx 35.2 \approx 35\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $4.0\text{ kg}$ object slides down an incline of $40^{\circ}$ with an acceleration of $2.5\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the magnitude of the kinetic friction force acting on the object.
questions.explanation: The net force down the incline is $mg\sin\theta - f_k = ma$. Thus $f_k = mg\sin\theta - ma = 4(9.8)(0.6428) - 4(2.5) = 25.18 - 10 = 15.18 \approx 15\text{ N}$.

questions.question: In an Atwood machine, masses $M_1 = 6.0\text{ kg}$ and $M_2 = 2.0\text{ kg}$ are connected by a light string over a frictionless, massless pulley. Calculate the tension in the cord while the masses are in motion.
questions.explanation: First find acceleration: $a = \frac{(6.0-2.0)(9.8)}{8} = \frac{4(9.8)}{8} = \frac{39.2}{8} = 4.9\text{ m/s}^2$. Then tension (using the smaller mass): $T = m_2(g + a) = 2(9.8 + 4.9) = 2(14.7) = 29.4 \approx 29\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $10\text{ kg}$ block on a horizontal frictionless table is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $5.0\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Starting from rest, calculate the distance the system moves in the first $2.0\text{ s}$.

A picture of mass $2.0\text{ kg}$ is hung by a wire that loops over a nail. The two segments of the wire make an angle of $100^{\circ}$ with each other. Calculate the tension in each segment of the wire.
questions.explanation: Each wire segment makes an angle of $50^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Vertical equilibrium: $2T\cos(50^{\circ}) = mg = 19.6\text{ N}$. Thus $T = 19.6/(2 \times 0.6428) = 19.6/1.2856 \approx 15.25 \approx 15\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A person of mass $70\text{ kg}$ is in an elevator that is decelerating downward at $1.5\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the normal force (apparent weight) acting on the person.
questions.explanation: Decelerating downward means the acceleration vector is upward, so $a = +1.5\text{ m/s}^2$. The normal force is $N = m(g + a) = 70(9.8 + 1.5) = 70(11.3) = 791 \approx 790\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A ceiling fan blade is $0.75\text{ m}$ long and rotates at $160\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Calculate the centripetal acceleration of the tip of the blade.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity: $\omega = 160 \times 2\pi/60 = 160 \times 0.10472 = 16.755\text{ rad/s}$. Centripetal acceleration: $a_c = \omega^2 r = (16.755)^2(0.75) = 280.7(0.75) \approx 210.5 \approx 210\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: An object moves in a circle of radius $2.5\text{ m}$ with a constant tangential speed of $8.0\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the period of the motion.

A mass of $0.30\text{ kg}$ is attached to a string of length $1.1\text{ m}$ and whirled in a vertical circle. At the top of the loop, its speed is $4.5\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the tension in the string at that instant.
questions.explanation: At the top, both tension and weight provide the centripetal force: $T + mg = mv^2/r$. Thus $T = m(v^2/r - g) = 0.30(4.5^2/1.1 - 9.8) = 0.30(20.25/1.1 - 9.8) = 0.30(18.41 - 9.8) = 0.30(8.61) \approx 2.583 \approx 2.6\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A pilot of mass $80\text{ kg}$ experiences an acceleration of $3.5\text{ g's}$ at the bottom of a dive while following a circular arc of radius $500\text{ m}$. Calculate the speed of the plane at that point.
questions.explanation: At the bottom, the normal force is $N = m(g + v^2/R) = 3.5mg$. Thus $g + v^2/R = 3.5g$, so $v^2/R = 2.5g$. Therefore $v = \sqrt{2.5gR} = \sqrt{2.5(9.8)(500)} = \sqrt{12250} \approx 110.7 \approx 110\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1400\text{ kg}$ rounds a flat, unbanked curve with a radius of $75\text{ m}$. If the coefficient of static friction between the tires and the road is $\mu_s = 0.70$, calculate the maximum constant speed the car can maintain without skidding.
questions.explanation: The maximum friction force provides the centripetal force: $\mu_s mg = mv^2/R$. Thus $v = \sqrt{\mu_s g R} = \sqrt{0.70 \times 9.8 \times 75} = \sqrt{514.5} \approx 22.68 \approx 23\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A ball of mass $0.40\text{ kg}$ is swung in a horizontal circle by a string of length $1.2\text{ m}$. If the tension in the string is $15\text{ N}$, calculate the frequency of rotation.
questions.explanation: For horizontal circular motion, tension provides the centripetal force: $T = m\omega^2 r \rightarrow \omega = \sqrt{T/(mr)} = \sqrt{15/(0.40 \times 1.2)} = \sqrt{31.25} = 5.59\text{ rad/s}$. Frequency: $f = \omega/2\pi = 5.59/6.283 \approx 0.890 \approx 0.89\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Calculate the gravitational force between two spheres, each of mass $8.0\text{ kg}$, whose centers are $0.40\text{ m}$ apart. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
If a planet has half the radius of Earth but the same mass, what is the acceleration due to gravity on its surface compared to Earth's? Calculate the value. (Take $g_{Earth} = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.)
questions.explanation: Gravitational acceleration: $g = GM/R^2$. For this planet: $g' = GM/(R/2)^2 = 4GM/R^2 = 4g = 4(9.8) = 39.2 \approx 39\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A sled of mass $20\text{ kg}$ is pulled a distance of $15\text{ m}$ across a horizontal snow-covered path by a constant force of $50\text{ N}$. If the work done by friction during this displacement is $-120\text{ J}$, calculate the net work done on the sled.
questions.explanation: Work done by the applied force: $W_{app} = Fd = 50 \times 15 = 750\text{ J}$. Work done by friction: $W_{fric} = -120\text{ J}$. Net work: $W_{net} = W_{app} + W_{fric} = 750 + (-120) = 630\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A ball of mass $0.25\text{ kg}$ is moving at $12\text{ m/s}$. How much work is required to increase its speed to $24\text{ m/s}$?
questions.explanation: Work equals change in kinetic energy: $W = \Delta KE = \frac{1}{2}m(v_f^2 - v_i^2) = 0.5(0.25)(24^2 - 12^2) = 0.125(576 - 144) = 0.125(432) = 54\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1200\text{ kg}$ traveling at $18\text{ m/s}$ is brought to a stop by a constant force over a distance of $35\text{ m}$. Calculate the magnitude of the force.
questions.explanation: First find acceleration using $v^2 = u^2 + 2as$: $0 = (18)^2 + 2a(35) \rightarrow 0 = 324 + 70a \rightarrow a = -324/70 = -4.629\text{ m/s}^2$. Then force: $F = m|a| = 1200(4.629) \approx 5554 \approx 5600\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $0.50\text{ kg}$ ball is thrown from the top of a $25\text{ m}$ high cliff with an initial speed of $14\text{ m/s}$. If it reaches the ground below with a speed of $20\text{ m/s}$, calculate the work done by air resistance during the fall.
questions.explanation: Initial total energy: $E_i = \frac{1}{2}mv_i^2 + mgh = 0.5(0.5)(14^2) + 0.5(9.8)(25) = 49 + 122.5 = 171.5\text{ J}$. Final kinetic energy: $E_f = \frac{1}{2}mv_f^2 = 0.5(0.5)(20^2) = 100\text{ J}$. Work done by air resistance = $E_f - E_i = 100 - 171.5 = -71.5 \approx -72\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $1.5\text{ kg}$ mass is attached to a horizontal spring with spring constant $k = 400\text{ N/m}$ and compressed by $0.15\text{ m}$ from its equilibrium position. Assuming no friction, calculate its speed as it passes through the equilibrium position.
questions.explanation: Conservation of energy: $\frac{1}{2}kx^2 = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \rightarrow v = \sqrt{\frac{kx^2}{m}} = \sqrt{\frac{400(0.15)^2}{1.5}} = \sqrt{\frac{400(0.0225)}{1.5}} = \sqrt{6} \approx 2.45 \approx 2.4\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A winch with a power output of $1.2\text{ kW}$ is used to lift a load of mass $250\text{ kg}$ vertically. Calculate the time it takes to lift the load a distance of $8.0\text{ m}$ at constant speed.

An engine outputs $60\text{ hp}$ ($1\text{ hp} = 746\text{ W}$) to keep a car moving at a constant speed of $32\text{ m/s}$ on a level road. Calculate the total resistive force (drag plus rolling resistance) opposing the motion.
questions.explanation: Power in watts: $P = 60 \times 746 = 44760\text{ W}$. At constant speed, $P = Fv$, so $F = P/v = 44760/32 \approx 1399 \approx 1400\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Calculate the additional elastic potential energy stored in a spring with spring constant $k = 120\text{ N/m}$ when it is stretched from an extension of $0.05\text{ m}$ to $0.15\text{ m}$.
A $5.0\text{ kg}$ mass is dropped from a height of $0.40\text{ m}$ onto a vertical spring. If the spring compresses by $0.12\text{ m}$, find the spring constant $k$. Neglect air resistance.
questions.explanation: By conservation of energy: $mg(h+x) = \frac{1}{2}kx^2$, where $x$ is the compression. $5(9.8)(0.40 + 0.12) = 0.5k(0.12)^2 \rightarrow 49(0.52) = 0.5k(0.0144) \rightarrow 25.48 = 0.0072k \rightarrow k = 25.48/0.0072 \approx 3539 \approx 3500\text{ N/m}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1500\text{ kg}$ moving North at $15\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on with a truck of mass $2000\text{ kg}$ moving South at $10\text{ m/s}$. If they lock bumpers together, calculate the final velocity of the combined wreck.
questions.explanation: Take North as positive. Initial momentum: $p_i = (1500)(15) + (2000)(-10) = 22500 - 20000 = 2500\text{ kg·m/s}$. Total mass: $1500 + 2000 = 3500\text{ kg}$. Final velocity: $v_f = p_i / 3500 = 2500/3500 \approx 0.714 \approx 0.71\text{ m/s North}$.

questions.question: A $2.0\text{ kg}$ ball moving at $4.0\text{ m/s}$ has a perfectly elastic head-on collision with a stationary $6.0\text{ kg}$ ball. Calculate the final velocity of the $6.0\text{ kg}$ ball.
questions.explanation: For an elastic collision where the target is initially at rest, $v_2 = \frac{2m_1}{m_1+m_2}u_1 = \frac{2(2.0)}{8.0}(4.0) = \frac{4}{8}(4.0) = 2.0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $4.0\text{ kg}$ object initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece has a mass of $1.2\text{ kg}$ and moves West at $25\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the velocity of the second piece.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $0 = (1.2)(-25) + (4.0 - 1.2)v_2 = -30 + 2.8v_2 \rightarrow v_2 = 30/2.8 \approx 10.71 \approx 11\text{ m/s}$. The positive sign indicates East, opposite to West.

questions.question: Three resistors with resistances $10\Omega$, $15\Omega$, and $25\Omega$ are connected in series to a $10\text{ V}$ battery. Calculate the power dissipated by the $15\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_{total} = 10 + 15 + 25 = 50\Omega$. Current: $I = V/R_{total} = 10/50 = 0.2\text{ A}$. Power in $15\Omega$ resistor: $P = I^2R = (0.2)^2(15) = 0.04 \times 15 = 0.60\text{ W}$.

questions.question: Two resistors are connected in series and have a total resistance of $120\Omega$. If one of the resistors is $30\Omega$, calculate the ratio of the voltages across the two resistors.
questions.explanation: The other resistor has resistance $120 - 30 = 90\Omega$. In a series circuit, voltage is proportional to resistance ($V = IR$ with same current). Thus $V_1:V_2 = R_1:R_2 = 30:90 = 1:3$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of resistors with values $20\Omega$, $40\Omega$, and $80\Omega$ connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: $\frac{1}{R_{eq}} = \frac{1}{20} + \frac{1}{40} + \frac{1}{80} = \frac{4}{80} + \frac{2}{80} + \frac{1}{80} = \frac{7}{80}$. Therefore $R_{eq} = 80/7 \approx 11.43 \approx 11\Omega$.

questions.question: A $24\text{ V}$ source is connected across two resistors wired in parallel. The total current drawn from the source is $3.0\text{ A}$, and one of the resistors is $12\Omega$. Find the value of the other resistor.
questions.explanation: Equivalent resistance: $R_{eq} = V/I = 24/3 = 8\Omega$. For two resistors in parallel: $\frac{1}{8} = \frac{1}{12} + \frac{1}{R_2} \rightarrow \frac{1}{R_2} = \frac{1}{8} - \frac{1}{12} = \frac{3}{24} - \frac{2}{24} = \frac{1}{24} \rightarrow R_2 = 24\Omega$.

questions.question: A $50\Omega$ resistor is connected in parallel with a $75\Omega$ resistor. This parallel combination is then connected in series with a $20\Omega$ resistor. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel combination gives $R_p = \frac{50 \times 75}{50 + 75} = \frac{3750}{125} = 30\Omega$. Adding the series $20\Omega$ resistor: $R_{total} = 30 + 20 = 50\Omega$.

questions.question: Find the current through the $20\Omega$ resistor in a circuit where it is connected in series with a parallel combination of two $30\Omega$ resistors, and the entire circuit is powered by a $12\text{ V}$ battery.
questions.explanation: The two $30\Omega$ resistors in parallel give $R_p = 30/2 = 15\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_{total} = 20 + 15 = 35\Omega$. Total current (which flows through the $20\Omega$ series resistor): $I = V/R_{total} = 12/35 \approx 0.343 \approx 0.34\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A string is $1.5\text{ m}$ long and has a total mass of $30\text{ g}$. If it is under a tension of $120\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of a wave on this string.
questions.explanation: Linear mass density: $\mu = m/L = 0.030/1.5 = 0.020\text{ kg/m}$. Wave speed: $v = \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{120/0.020} = \sqrt{6000} \approx 77.46 \approx 77\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A wave has a frequency of $25\text{ Hz}$. The distance between a crest and the adjacent trough is $0.60\text{ m}$. Calculate the speed of the wave.
questions.explanation: The distance from a crest to the adjacent trough is half a wavelength, so $\lambda/2 = 0.60\text{ m} \rightarrow \lambda = 1.20\text{ m}$. Wave speed: $v = f\lambda = 25 \times 1.20 = 30\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An ambulance siren emits sound at a frequency of $600\text{ Hz}$. A stationary observer hears the siren at $640\text{ Hz}$ as the ambulance approaches. Calculate the speed of the ambulance. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For a source approaching a stationary observer: $f' = f\frac{v}{v - v_s}$. Substituting: $640 = 600\frac{340}{340 - v_s} \rightarrow \frac{640}{600} = \frac{340}{340 - v_s} \rightarrow 1.0667 = \frac{340}{340 - v_s} \rightarrow 340 - v_s = 340/1.0667 = 318.75 \rightarrow v_s = 340 - 318.75 = 21.25 \approx 21\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Two speakers emit sound in phase. At a point where the path difference from the speakers is $0.90\text{ m}$, destructive interference occurs. Calculate the frequency of the sound, assuming the longest possible wavelength. The speed of sound is $344\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For destructive interference with sources in phase, the condition is $\Delta = (n + \frac{1}{2})\lambda$. For the longest wavelength, take $n = 0$, giving $0.90 = \lambda/2 \rightarrow \lambda = 1.80\text{ m}$. Then $f = v/\lambda = 344/1.80 \approx 191.1 \approx 190\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Calculate the fundamental frequency of an organ pipe that is $45\text{ cm}$ long and closed at one end. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For a closed pipe, the fundamental wavelength is $\lambda = 4L = 4(0.45) = 1.80\text{ m}$. The fundamental frequency is $f = v/\lambda = 340/1.80 \approx 188.9 \approx 190\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Two sound waves of frequencies $200\text{ Hz}$ and $205\text{ Hz}$ interfere. Calculate the time interval between successive loud pulses (beats).
questions.explanation: The beat frequency is $f_{beat} = |205 - 200| = 5\text{ Hz}$. The period of the beats (time between successive loud pulses) is $T_{beat} = 1/f_{beat} = 1/5 = 0.20\text{ s}$.
